<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 217, 907, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1) **October/November 2013**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 238, 907, 252]]<|/det|>
**1 hour 45 minutes**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 260, 190, 273]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 260, 455, 273]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 323, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
# READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 352, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 368, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 497, 415]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 601, 431]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 285, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 907, 493]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 588, 508]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 509, 606, 524]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 556, 756, 571]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 907, 618]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 865, 660, 879]]<|/det|>
This document consists of 4 printed pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 400, 92]]<|/det|>
Solve the inequality \(x^{2} - x - 2 > 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 125, 96, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 123, 828, 144]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\). It is given that \(\mathrm{f}^{\prime}(x) = x^{-\frac{3}{2}} + 1\) and that \(\mathrm{f}(4) = 5\). Find \(\mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 172, 96, 191]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 170, 920, 206]]<|/det|>
The point \(A\) has coordinates (3, 1) and the point \(B\) has coordinates \((-21, 11)\). The point \(C\) is the mid-point of \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 217, 153, 235]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 217, 747, 236]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the line through \(A\) that is perpendicular to \(y = 2x - 7\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 217, 920, 236]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 248, 153, 267]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 248, 336, 267]]<|/det|>
Find the distance \(AC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 249, 920, 267]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 295, 92, 312]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 303, 675, 549]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 920, 640]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a pyramid \(OABC\) in which the edge \(OC\) is vertical. The horizontal base \(OAB\) is a triangle, right-angled at \(O\), and \(D\) is the mid-point of \(AB\). The edges \(OA\), \(OB\) and \(OC\) have lengths of 8 units, 6 units and 10 units respectively. The unit vectors \(\mathbf{i}\), \(\mathbf{j}\) and \(\mathbf{k}\) are parallel to \(\overrightarrow{OA}\), \(\overrightarrow{OB}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OC}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 657, 151, 676]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 656, 655, 676]]<|/det|>
Express each of the vectors \(\overrightarrow{OD}\) and \(\overrightarrow{CD}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{i}\), \(\mathbf{j}\) and \(\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 657, 920, 676]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 688, 153, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 688, 482, 707]]<|/det|>
Use a scalar product to find angle \(ODC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 689, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 735, 96, 754]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 736, 146, 754]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 736, 920, 769]]<|/det|>
In a geometric progression, the sum to infinity is equal to eight times the first term. Find the common ratio.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 752, 920, 770]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 784, 146, 802]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 782, 920, 816]]<|/det|>
In an arithmetic progression, the fifth term is 197 and the sum of the first ten terms is 2040. Find the common difference.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 798, 920, 816]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 83, 670, 247]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 262, 920, 300]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows sector \(OAB\) with centre \(O\) and radius \(11 \mathrm{cm}\). Angle \(AOB = \alpha\) radians. Points \(C\) and \(D\) lie on \(OA\) and \(OB\) respectively. Arc \(CD\) has centre \(O\) and radius \(5 \mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 312, 153, 330]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 311, 920, 345]]<|/det|>
The area of the shaded region \(ABDC\) is equal to \(k\) times the area of the unshaded region \(OCD\). Find \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 330, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 357, 153, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 356, 920, 392]]<|/det|>
The perimeter of the shaded region \(ABCD\) is equal to twice the perimeter of the unshaded region \(OCD\). Find the exact value of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 375, 920, 393]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 418, 96, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 418, 144, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 418, 920, 453]]<|/det|>
Find the possible values of \(x\) for which \(\sin^{-1}(x^{2} - 1) = \frac{1}{3}\pi\), giving your answers correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 437, 920, 456]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 466, 144, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 465, 868, 486]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\sin (2\theta + \frac{1}{3}\pi) = \frac{1}{2}\) for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \pi\), giving \(\theta\) in terms of \(\pi\) in your answers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 465, 920, 485]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 518, 96, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 517, 154, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 516, 608, 537]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of \(x^{8}\) in the expansion of \(\left(x + 3x^{2}\right)^{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 518, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 553, 153, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 552, 608, 573]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of \(x^{8}\) in the expansion of \(\left(x + 3x^{2}\right)^{5}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 588, 153, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 587, 700, 609]]<|/det|>
Hence find the coefficient of \(x^{8}\) in the expansion of \(\left[1 + \left(x + 3x^{2}\right)\right]^{5}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 590, 920, 609]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 648, 96, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 640, 923, 686]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \frac{k^2}{x + 2} + x\), where \(k\) is a positive constant. Find, in terms of \(k\), the values of \(x\) for which the curve has stationary points and determine the nature of each stationary point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 670, 920, 688]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 715, 106, 734]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 714, 920, 750]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined by f : x ↦→ x² + 4x for x ⩾ c, where c is a constant. It is given that f is a one-one function.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 762, 151, 780]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 762, 745, 781]]<|/det|>
State the range of f in terms of \(c\) and find the smallest possible value of \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 763, 920, 781]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 793, 920, 828]]<|/det|>
The function g is defined by \(\mathrm{g}:x\mapsto ax + b\) for \(x\geqslant 0\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are positive constants. It is given that, when \(c = 0\), \(\mathrm{gf}(1) = 11\) and \(\mathrm{fg}(1) = 21\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 840, 153, 858]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 840, 813, 858]]<|/det|>
Write down two equations in \(a\) and \(b\) and solve them to find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 840, 920, 858]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 880, 675, 900]]<|/det|>
[Question 11 is printed on the next page.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 81, 776, 273]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 291, 512, 310]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = \sqrt{(x^4 + 4x + 4)}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 323, 151, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 323, 665, 342]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the tangent to the curve at the point (0, 2).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 323, 918, 341]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 354, 153, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 354, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
Show that the \(x\)-coordinates of the points of intersection of the line \(y = x + 2\) and the curve are given by the equation \((x + 2)^2 = x^4 + 4x + 4\). Hence find these \(x\)-coordinates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 370, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 401, 151, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 401, 920, 434]]<|/det|>
The region shaded in the diagram is rotated through \(360^{\circ}\) about the \(x\)-axis. Find the volume of revolution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 419, 920, 437]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
